section: A. The Members wish to enter into an association of mutual benefit and agree to jointly invest and set up a joint venture enterprise. B. This Agreement sets out the terms and conditions governing this association. IN CONSIDERATION OF and as a condition of the Members entering into this Agreement and other valuable consideration, the receipt and sufficiency of which consideration is acknowledged, the Members agree as follows:
explanation: The phrase "other valuable consideration, the receipt and sufficiency of which consideration is acknowledged" is boilerplate language that is ambiguous. It does not specify what this 'other valuable consideration' is. This lack of specificity can lead to disputes later on, as one party may claim a certain action or item was part of this consideration, while the other party disagrees.

section: The exclusive purpose of the Venture (the "Purpose") will be IT Development. internet Back office Maintenance And Deployment of medical Service.
explanation: The description of the Venture's purpose is vague and poorly structured. "IT Development. internet Back office Maintenance And Deployment of medical Service" is not a clear and concise statement of purpose. The terms are not well-defined, and the use of "internet" without specifying what aspect of the internet is relevant creates ambiguity. It's unclear what kind of 'medical service' is being deployed and how the IT development supports this.

section: JVLS, LLC dba Vaccines 2Go $60,000.00 USD From Monthly Government , City And State, And Or Private Awarded Contracts. Plus (10%) Of Any Generated Gross Revenue From Awarded Contract, In Addition to The Total Contributions.
explanation: The description of JVLS, LLC's duties and contribution is confusing and potentially contradictory. It states "$60,000.00 USD From Monthly Government , City And State, And Or Private Awarded Contracts," implying this is how the $60,000 will be sourced, which may not be guaranteed. Additionally, the phrase "Plus (10%) Of Any Generated Gross Revenue From Awarded Contract, In Addition to The Total Contributions" creates uncertainty. Is the 10% included in the $60,000, or is it above and beyond this amount? How is the 10% of revenue 'in addition to total contributions'? If the $60,000 is sourced from contracts, and revenue is generated from those contracts, it creates an unclear situation of how the 10% works.

section: Each of the Members has contributed to the capital of the Venture, in cash or property in agreed upon value, as follows (the "Capital Contribution"): Member Contribution Description Agreed Value BorrowMoney.com, inc 1, 500 square feet of Leased/rent office Space Includingspecified Description of duty* $3,500,000.00 USD JVLS, LLC dba Vaccines 2Go $60,000.00 USD From Monthly Government , City And State, And Or Private Awarded Contracts. Plus (10%) Of Any Generated Gross Revenue, In Add i t i on to The To ta l Contributions. $3,500,000.00 USD
explanation: The agreed value of BorrowMoney.com, inc's contribution (1,500 sq ft of leased/rent office space) is stated as $3,500,000.00 USD. This is highly improbable and suggests a significant overvaluation. Similarly, JVLS, LLC contributing $60,000 plus a percentage of revenue also being valued at $3,500,000 is equally improbable. This discrepancy raises concerns about the fairness and accuracy of the capital contributions and the overall financial structure of the joint venture. Furthermore, by assigning the same monetary value to each parties' contribution even though one contribution comes with additional stipulations, an inconsistency is created.

section: In the absence of a written agreement setting a value, the value of the Venture will be determined based on the fair market value appraisal of all Venture assets (less liabilities) in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles (GAAP) by an independent accounting firm agreed to by all Members. An appraiser will be appointed within a reasonable period of the date of withdrawal or dissolution. The results of the appraisal will be binding on all Members.
explanation: The term "reasonable period" is ambiguous. It doesn't define a specific timeframe for appointing an appraiser, which could lead to disagreements and delays during a withdrawal or dissolution. Without a defined timeframe, it is open to interpretation and could result in legal disputes.

section: Force Majeure 43. A Member will be free of liability to the Venture where the Member is prevented from executing their obligations under this Agreement in whole or in part due to force majeure where the Member has communicated the circumstance of that event to any and all other Members and taken any and all appropriate action to mitigate that event. Force majeure will include, but not be limited to, earthquake, typhoon, flood, fire, and war or any other unforeseen and uncontrollable event.
explanation: The phrase "any and all appropriate action to mitigate that event" is vague. It doesn't specify what constitutes 'appropriate action' or who determines its appropriateness. This ambiguity creates uncertainty about the level of effort a member must undertake to mitigate the effects of a force majeure event to be relieved of liability. Leaving this detail unspecified allows for interpretation.
